description: In this century of institutional development, national expansion, and sectional conflict,
Americans continued to define a national identity. Students probe the ways in which
region, religion, race, ethnicity, and gender inform individual and group contributions
to the conversation. They also analyze how geographical expansion and ideas of progress
influenced different visions and versions of America. Topics and texts range from
Transcendentalist writers, the Second Great Awakening, and Black Elk Speaks to
landscape painting and Western photography. Offered annually in the spring semester.
Counts toward American studies major. Prerequisite: AMCON 101.
